awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Scaling of AlN/GaN/AlN HEMTs via molecular beam epitaxy
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project addresses range limitations associated with next-generation high-frequency communication systems, a pain point shared by commercial and defense sectors. Millimeter-wave defense radar systems provide more accurate mapping of a landscape or objects, but have reduced range capabilities compared to standard radar systems. This reduced range also affects the telecommunication industry and motivates building more base stations to provide high-frequency 5G coverage over large areas. By increasing range via an aluminum nitride-enhanced power amplifier, this project aims to increase the object detection limit of defense radar systems and maximum base station coverage by up to 40%. This will enable more improved performance for defense application and also reduce the number of base stations necessary for future (6G and beyond) telecommunication networks.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project aims to scale aluminum nitride as a new material platform for high-power, high-frequency power amplifiers. Current power amplifier materials, typically silicon and gallium nitride, are often constrained by heat and voltage limitations. By incorporating aluminum nitride, this project can potentially improve power amplifier power density by two-fold, and provides 25% lower temperature operation at the same power level as conventional power amplifiers. Towards these goals, this STTR project will scale up the aluminum nitride platform and target commercially relevant discrete transistor yields.  The targeted minimum viable product is an aluminum nitride platform microwave monolithically integrated circuit.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Soctera is working to develop next generation power amplifier solutions for defense radar and 5G telecommunication. Soctera's innovation lies in its transition from the conventional gallium nitride (GaN) structure to majority aluminum nitride (AlN) heterostructure for significantly more efficient and cooler transistors - addressing a critical pain point of today's thermally-restricted power amplifiers.

This project aimed to demonstrate the scalability of Soctera's technology by scaling the material growth and transistor fabrication from 1x1 cm2 samples to 3-inch diameter wafers. The small, 1x1 cm2 wafers do not have consistent electronic properties from piece to piece and are not cost-efficient for commercial amplifier production. This project studied molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) techniques such as element ratios, rotation speed, and growth temperatures to maximize the uniformity of the AlN layers. Uniform material growth across the 3-inch wafer was achieved, and shown to be repeatable.

Once viable 3-inch wafers were available, Soctera began developing a fabrication process for high frequency transistors at 3-inch scale. Etch recipes were checked for uniformity, and new modules were created for photolithography. Most significantly, an electron beam lithography process (required for high-power, high-frequency performance) was developed that enabled relatively quick exposure time for 100+ dies, with alignment accuracy of approximately 10 nanometers.

Ultimately, high frequency transistors fabricated on the 3-inch wafers were measured at and above the frequencies used by today's radars and telecommunication systems (up to 94 Gigahertz). At all measured frequencies, the transistors showed high gain, with efficiencies and power levels comparable to other GaN-buffer technologies. With these results, Soctera achieved its technical goals for the project.

Soctera also used the NSF Phase I STTR to begin growth of its AlN structure via metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD), a method considered to be more commercial than MBE. Initial results have demonstrated a similar structure as that grown via MBE, with electronic properties beginning to be measured.

Beyond the technical accomplishments, this project supported foundational development of Soctera's minimum viable product. This minimum viable product, a power amplifier enhanced with aluminum nitride, aims to drastically increase communication distances of cellular base stations and radar networks. In doing so, Soctera hopes to enable the next generation of wireless communication that will connect and protect the nation.


Last Modified: 11/28/2022
Modified by: Austin Hickman

Image
  • The scaling of Soctera's technology that was accomplished under the NSF Phase I STTR grant. The left sample is 1x1 cm2, the right is a 3-inch diameter wafer.
    Austin Hickman
    Austin Hickman
    Scaling
